item.title: Covid-19: Shielding coming to an end for millions
item.description: People seen as clinically extremely vulnerable are still being told to take precautions over Covid.

item.title: George Floyd: Teenage witness 'stays up apologising for not doing more'
item.description: Derek Chauvin's trial hears gripping testimony from young witnesses to George Floyd's death.

item.title: Scotland election 2021: Party leaders clash over need for indyref2
item.description: The leaders of the country's five larger parties went head-to-head in a live BBC Scotland debate.

item.title: Covid: Germany limits use of AstraZeneca Covid jab for under-60s
item.description: The vaccine maker stresses that regulators find the benefits of its Covid-19 shot outweigh the risks.

item.title: Speaker Lord Fowler backs calls for National Aids memorial
item.description: Lord Fowler, the Lord Speaker of the House of Lords, has backed calls for the UK’s first ever National Aids Memorial.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: Brazil military chiefs resign in new crisis for Bolsonaro
item.description: It comes amid a cabinet reshuffle as Jair Bolsonaro fights to contain a crisis over his leadership.

item.title: 'Sobriety ankle tags' rolled out across England
item.description: The electronic tags monitor offenders' sweat to see if they are breaching court-ordered drinking bans.

item.title: Brexit: UK 'risks falling behind' EU on workers’ rights
item.description: The EU is working to improve conditions but the UK is not keeping pace, says the TUC.

item.title: Biden's dog Major bites again at White House
item.description: Major had been sent to Delaware for training after nipping a White House employee earlier this month.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to help health workers' mental health
item.description: The BBC's Laura Foster gets tips from NHS staff working in the profession.

item.title: Outdoor UK attractions fared better during pandemic
item.description: Kew Gardens and RHS Wisley feature in the top 10 most visited attractions for the first time.

item.title: A few frequent flyers 'dominate air travel'
item.description: A small minority of frequent flyers dominates air travel in countries with high aviation emissions.

item.title: The Papers: Diverse UK 'hailed' and 'keep your cool'
item.description: A government review's finding that the UK is a model on race for other countries is among the front-page stories.

item.title: No end in sight for India's protesting farmers
item.description: Indian farmers are protesting against three new laws they believe will hurt their income.

item.title: London house turned into House of Dreams work of art
item.description: Artist Stephen Wright has been turning his London house into a work of art since 1998.

item.title: Myanmar coup: The monks divided over the deadly protests
item.description: Hundreds have been killed in deadly protests since the military took control of the country in February.

item.title: Capturing every hour of each New Year's Day for 24 years
item.description: The 18th year of 24 photographers documenting every hour of New Year's Day, each year, for 24 years.

item.title: In Pictures: UK March temperature highest for 53 years
item.description: Some parts of the UK enjoyed spring sunshine as the UK recorded its warmest March day since 1968.

item.title: What did we learn from Scotland election debate?
item.description: The party leaders all called each other by their first names - but the deep divisions between them showed.

item.title: Schoolmates Ollie and Jacob on TikTok fame
item.description: Ollie and his best mate, Jacob, have become the comedy duo everyone's talking about on TikTok.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'The stress of being a boss made my hair fall out'
item.description: An entrepreneur explains the strategy he devised to protect himself from mental burnout.

item.title: Mayor of London: Two decades in the spotlight
item.description: BBC London's Political Editor Tim Donovan looks at the moments that defined the role of mayor of London.

item.title: Scalping: The teens making thousands selling consoles online
item.description: If you've been struggling to buy a new PlayStation or Xbox, this might be the reason why.

item.title: Gatwick Airport: Can Crawley turn away from aviation and go green?
item.description: A year after British Airways grounded flights at Gatwick Airport, nearby Crawley plots a new course.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Leaders' debate fact-checked
item.description: Reality Check looks at claims about child poverty, renewable energy and mental health.

item.title: Oscars 2021: The female directors tackling tough truths
item.description: Two international film nominees on the personal trials they faced making their hard-hitting films.

item.title: Gambling apps: a super casino in your pocket
item.description: There are concerns over the way that gambling companies use the data collected on their customers.

item.title: James earns Wales late win in fiery World Cup qualifier
item.description: Daniel James' late header gives Wales victory over the Czech Republic in a fiery World Cup qualifier in which both teams had a man sent off.

item.title: Kenny's winless start continues as Republic held to friendly draw by Qatar
item.description: The Republic of Ireland fail to secure a first win under manager Stephen Kenny as they are held to a 1-1 friendly draw with Qatar in Debrecen.

item.title: England U21 job 'utterly impossible' says manager Boothroyd
item.description: England Under-21 manager Aidy Boothroyd believes his job is "utterly impossible" with his side facing a second successive group stage exit from the European Championships.

item.title: Jota and Ronaldo rescue Portugal against Luxembourg
item.description: Diogo Jota and Cristiano Ronaldo score to help spare Portugal's blushes and deny Luxembourg another major World Cup 2022 qualifying win.

item.title: Herring's late arrival in UAE 'a mistake' - Frampton
item.description: Carl Frampton says champion Jamel Herring's decision to arrive in Dubai only a week before their world title fight is "absolutely a mistake".

item.title: New Women's Six Nations format set to be one-off
item.description: The new format of the Women's Six Nations is likely to only be for 2021 organisers have confirmed.

item.title: What are the rules on dating now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 30 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms, pubs and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid passports: What are different countries planning?
item.description: How advanced are some countries' plans for vaccine certificates and Covid passports?

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Where is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine made?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid rules: What is the rule of six in England?
item.description: The rule of six is back for England from Monday but with some changes - we explain what they are.

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport to go to the pub or travel abroad?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: India coronavirus: Why have vaccine exports been suspended?
item.description: India is a big player in vaccine production - but companies are warning of supply problems.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Side effects and why it can’t give you the virus
item.description: It's normal to experience some mild side effects, such as a headache or a raised temperature.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
